attributes.value: [001] # Bitcoin: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Cash System
[003] author: Satoshi Nakamoto
[005] email: <satoshin@gmx.com>
[007] site: <http://www.bitcoin.org>
[009] ## Abstract
[011] A purely peer-to-peer version of electronic cash
[012] would allow online payments to be sent directly
[013] from one party to another without going through a
[014] financial institution. Digital signatures provide
[015] part of the solution, but the main benefits are
[016] lost if a trusted third party is still required to
[017] prevent double-spending. We propose a solution to
[018] the double-spending problem using a peer-to-peer
[019] network. The network timestamps transactions by
[020] hashing them into an ongoing chain of hash-based
[021] proof-of-work, forming a record that cannot be
[022] changed without redoing the proof-of-work. The
[023] longest chain not only serves as proof of the
[024] sequence of events witnessed, but proof that it
[025] came from the largest pool of CPU power. As long
[026] as a majority of CPU power is controlled by nodes
[027] that are not cooperating to attack the network,
[028] they\'ll generate the longest chain and outpace
[029] attackers. The network itself requires minimal
[030] structure. Messages are broadcast on a best effort
[031] basis, and nodes can leave and rejoin the network
[032] at will, accepting the longest proof-of-work chain
[033] as proof of what happened while they were gone.
[035] ## Introduction
[037] Commerce on the Internet has come to rely almost
[038] exclusively on financial institutions serving as
[039] trusted third parties to process electronic
[040] payments. While the system works well enough for
[041] most transactions, it still suffers from the
[042] inherent weaknesses of the trust based model.
[043] Completely non-reversible transactions are not
[044] really possible, since financial institutions
[045] cannot avoid mediating disputes. The cost of
[046] mediation increases transaction costs, limiting
[047] the minimum practical transaction size and cutting
[048] off the possibility for small casual transactions,
[049] and there is a broader cost in the loss of ability
[050] to make non-reversible payments for nonreversible
[051] services. With the possibility of reversal, the
[052] need for trust spreads. Merchants must be wary of
[053] their customers, hassling them for more
[054] information than they would otherwise need. A
[055] certain percentage of fraud is accepted as
[056] unavoidable. These costs and payment uncertainties
[057] can be avoided in person by using physical
[058] currency, but no mechanism exists to make payments
[059] over a communications channel without a trusted
[060] party.
[062] What is needed is an electronic payment system
[063] based on cryptographic proof instead of trust,
[064] allowing any two willing parties to transact
[065] directly with each other without the need for a
[066] trusted third party. Transactions that are
[067] computationally impractical to reverse would
[068] protect sellers from fraud, and routine escrow
[069] mechanisms could easily be implemented to protect
[070] buyers. In this paper, we propose a solution to
[071] the double-spending problem using a peer-to-peer
[072] distributed timestamp server to generate
[073] computational proof of the chronological order of
[074] transactions. The system is secure as long as
[075] honest nodes collectively control more CPU power
[076] than any cooperating group of attacker nodes.
[078] ## Transactions
[080] We define an electronic coin as a chain of digital
[081] signatures. Each owner transfers the coin to the
[082] next by digitally signing a hash of the previous
[083] transaction and the public key of the next owner
[084] and adding these to the end of the coin. A payee
[085] can verify the signatures to verify the chain of
[086] ownership.
[088] ![ca83be2e4063da3530a4434fef9e23eb2c4b995ee3945159b5a903462323a86a](img/transactions.png)
[090] The problem of course is the payee can\'t verify
[091] that one of the owners did not double-spend the
[092] coin. A common solution is to introduce a trusted
[093] central authority, or mint, that checks every
[094] transaction for double spending. After each
[095] transaction, the coin must be returned to the mint
[096] to issue a new coin, and only coins issued
[097] directly from the mint are trusted not to be
[098] double-spent. The problem with this solution is
[099] that the fate of the entire money system depends
[100] on the company running the mint, with every
[101] transaction having to go through them, just like a
[102] bank.
[104] We need a way for the payee to know that the
[105] previous owners did not sign any earlier
[106] transactions. For our purposes, the earliest
[107] transaction is the one that counts, so we don\'t
[108] care about later attempts to double-spend. The
[109] only way to confirm the absence of a transaction
[110] is to be aware of all transactions. In the mint
[111] based model, the mint was aware of all
[112] transactions and decided which arrived first. To
[113] accomplish this without a trusted party,
[114] transactions must be publicly announced[^1], and
[115] we need a system for participants to agree on a
[116] single history of the order in which they were
[117] received. The payee needs proof that at the time
[118] of each transaction, the majority of nodes agreed
[119] it was the first received.
[121] ## Timestamp Server
[123] The solution we propose begins with a timestamp
[124] server. A timestamp server works by taking a hash
[125] of a block of items to be timestamped and widely
[126] publishing the hash, such as in a newspaper or
[127] Usenet post[^2][^3][^4][^5]. The timestamp proves
[128] that the data must have existed at the time,
[129] obviously, in order to get into the hash. Each
[130] timestamp includes the previous timestamp in its
[131] hash, forming a chain, with each additional
[132] timestamp reinforcing the ones before it.
[134] ![625cdf335ab25f3cc7dc53b2864adb38f4ab611e7458aff716fbb0c9836a6e39](img/timestamp.png)
[136] ## Proof-of-Work
[138] To implement a distributed timestamp server on a
[139] peer-to-peer basis, we will need to use a
[140] proof-of-work system similar to Adam Back\'s
[141] Hashcash [^6], rather than newspaper or Usenet
[142] posts. The proof-of-work involves scanning for a
[143] value that when hashed, such as with SHA-256, the
[144] hash begins with a number of zero bits. The
[145] average work required is exponential in the number
[146] of zero bits required and can be verified by
[147] executing a single hash.
[149] For our timestamp network, we implement the
[150] proof-of-work by incrementing a nonce in the block
[151] until a value is found that gives the block\'s
[152] hash the required zero bits. Once the CPU effort
[153] has been expended to make it satisfy the
[154] proof-of-work, the block cannot be changed without
[155] redoing the work. As later blocks are chained
[156] after it, the work to change the block would
[157] include redoing all the blocks after it.
[161] The proof-of-work also solves the problem of
[162] determining representation in majority decision
[163] making. If the majority were based on
[164] one-IP-address-one-vote, it could be subverted by
[165] anyone able to allocate many IPs. Proof-of-work is
[166] essentially one-CPU-one-vote. The majority
[167] decision is represented by the longest chain,
[168] which has the greatest proof-of-work effort
[169] invested in it. If a majority of CPU power is
[170] controlled by honest nodes, the honest chain will
[171] grow the fastest and outpace any competing chains.
[172] To modify a past block, an attacker would have to
[173] redo the proof-of-work of the block and all blocks
[174] after it and then catch up with and surpass the
[175] work of the honest nodes. We will show later that
[176] the probability of a slower attacker catching up
[177] diminishes exponentially as subsequent blocks are
[178] added.
[180] To compensate for increasing hardware speed and
[181] varying interest in running nodes over time, the
[182] proof-of-work difficulty is determined by a moving
[183] average targeting an average number of blocks per
[184] hour. If they\'re generated too fast, the
[185] difficulty increases.
[187] ## Network
[189] The steps to run the network are as follows:
[191] 1.  New transactions are broadcast to all nodes.
[192] 2.  Each node collects new transactions into a block.
[193] 3.  Each node works on finding a difficult
[194]     proof-of-work for its block.
[195] 4.  When a node finds a proof-of-work, it
[196]     broadcasts the block to all nodes.
[197] 5.  Nodes accept the block only if all transactions
[198]     in it are valid and not already spent.
[199] 6.  Nodes express their acceptance of the block by
[200]     working on creating the next block in the chain,
[201]     using the hash of the accepted block as the
[202]     previous hash.
[204] Nodes always consider the longest chain to be the
[205] correct one and will keep working on extending it.
[206] If two nodes broadcast different versions of the
[207] next block simultaneously, some nodes may receive
[208] one or the other first. In that case, they work on
[209] the first one they received, but save the other
[210] branch in case it becomes longer. The tie will be
[211] broken when the next proof-of-work is found and
[212] one branch becomes longer; the nodes that were
[213] working on the other branch will then switch to
[214] the longer one.
[216] New transaction broadcasts do not necessarily need
[217] to reach all nodes. As long as they reach many
[218] nodes, they will get into a block before long.
[219] Block broadcasts are also tolerant of dropped
[220] messages. If a node does not receive a block, it
[221] will request it when it receives the next block
[222] and realizes it missed one.
[224] ## Incentive
[226] By convention, the first transaction in a block is
[227] a special transaction that starts a new coin owned
[228] by the creator of the block. This adds an
[229] incentive for nodes to support the network, and
[230] provides a way to initially distribute coins into
[231] circulation, since there is no central authority
[232] to issue them. The steady addition of a constant
[233] of amount of new coins is analogous to gold miners
[234] expending resources to add gold to circulation. In
[235] our case, it is CPU time and electricity that is
[236] expended.
[238] The incentive can also be funded with transaction
[239] fees. If the output value of a transaction is less
[240] than its input value, the difference is a
[241] transaction fee that is added to the incentive
[242] value of the block containing the transaction.
[243] Once a predetermined number of coins have entered
[244] circulation, the incentive can transition entirely
[245] to transaction fees and be completely inflation
[246] free.
[248] The incentive may help encourage nodes to stay
[249] honest. If a greedy attacker is able to assemble
[250] more CPU power than all the honest nodes, he would
[251] have to choose between using it to defraud people
[252] by stealing back his payments, or using it to
[253] generate new coins. He ought to find it more
[254] profitable to play by the rules, such rules that
[255] favour him with more new coins than everyone else
[256] combined, than to undermine the system and the
[257] validity of his own wealth.
[259] ## Reclaiming Disk Space
[261] Once the latest transaction in a coin is buried
[262] under enough blocks, the spent transactions before
[263] it can be discarded to save disk space. To
[264] facilitate this without breaking the block\'s
[265] hash, transactions are hashed in a Merkle
[266] Tree[^7][^2][^5], with only the root included in
[267] the block\'s hash. Old blocks can then be
[268] compacted by stubbing off branches of the tree.
[269] The interior hashes do not need to be stored.
[273] A block header with no transactions would be about
[274] 80 bytes. If we suppose blocks are generated every
[276] year. With computer systems typically selling with
[277] 2GB of RAM as of 2008, and Moore\'s Law predicting
[278] current growth of 1.2GB per year, storage should
[279] not be a problem even if the block headers must be
[280] kept in memory.
[282] ## Simplified Payment Verification
[284] It is possible to verify payments without running
[285] a full network node. A user only needs to keep a
[286] copy of the block headers of the longest
[287] proof-of-work chain, which he can get by querying
[288] network nodes until he\'s convinced he has the
[289] longest chain, and obtain the Merkle branch
[290] linking the transaction to the block it\'s
[291] timestamped in. He can\'t check the transaction
[292] for himself, but by linking it to a place in the
[293] chain, he can see that a network node has accepted
[294] it, and blocks added after it further confirm the
[295] network has accepted it.
[297] ![4bc01a5aa2d6ae9d2bd0ad18d2eb09ded6c31112a77f3890dad3708e931a4ace](img/spv.png)
[299] As such, the verification is reliable as long as
[300] honest nodes control the network, but is more
[301] vulnerable if the network is overpowered by an
[302] attacker. While network nodes can verify
[303] transactions for themselves, the simplified method
[304] can be fooled by an attacker\'s fabricated
[305] transactions for as long as the attacker can
[306] continue to overpower the network. One strategy to
[307] protect against this would be to accept alerts
[308] from network nodes when they detect an invalid
[309] block, prompting the user\'s software to download
[310] the full block and alerted transactions to confirm
[311] the inconsistency. Businesses that receive
[312] frequent payments will probably still want to run
[313] their own nodes for more independent security and
[314] quicker verification.
[316] ## Combining and Splitting Value
[318] Although it would be possible to handle coins
[319] individually, it would be unwieldy to make a
[320] separate transaction for every cent in a transfer.
[321] To allow value to be split and combined,
[322] transactions contain multiple inputs and outputs.
[323] Normally there will be either a single input from
[324] a larger previous transaction or multiple inputs
[325] combining smaller amounts, and at most two
[326] outputs: one for the payment, and one returning
[327] the change, if any, back to the sender.
[329] ![b52f32d67576ca9ae3116735a37bac48252ce45f3b897c3474ed206f8ab79af0](img/combining-splitting.png)
[331] It should be noted that fan-out, where a
[332] transaction depends on several transactions, and
[333] those transactions depend on many more, is not a
[334] problem here. There is never the need to extract a
[335] complete standalone copy of a transaction\'s
[336] history.
[338] ## Privacy The traditional banking model achieves
[339] a level of privacy by limiting access to
[340] information to the parties involved and the
[341] trusted third party. The necessity to announce all
[342] transactions publicly precludes this method, but
[343] privacy can still be maintained by breaking the
[344] flow of information in another place: by keeping
[345] public keys anonymous. The public can see that
[346] someone is sending an amount to someone else, but
[347] without information linking the transaction to
[348] anyone. This is similar to the level of
[349] information released by stock exchanges, where the
[350] time and size of individual trades, the \'tape\',
[351] is made public, but without telling who the
[352] parties were.
[354] ![11fb5f6975e7b9cb13791239b2fde4ddfac1d0cc646e56f09f48668dd6858011](img/privacy.png)
[356] As an additional firewall, a new key pair should
[357] be used for each transaction to keep them from
[358] being linked to a common owner. Some linking is
[359] still unavoidable with multi-input transactions,
[360] which necessarily reveal that their inputs were
[361] owned by the same owner. The risk is that if the
[362] owner of a key is revealed, linking could reveal
[363] other transactions that belonged to the same owner.
[365] ## Calculations
[367] We consider the scenario of an attacker trying to
[368] generate an alternate chain faster than the honest
[369] chain. Even if this is accomplished, it does not
[370] throw the system open to arbitrary changes, such
[371] as creating value out of thin air or taking money
[372] that never belonged to the attacker. Nodes are not
[373] going to accept an invalid transaction as payment,
[374] and honest nodes will never accept a block
[375] containing them. An attacker can only try to
[376] change one of his own transactions to take back
[377] money he recently spent.
[379] The race between the honest chain and an attacker
[380] chain can be characterized as a Binomial Random
[381] Walk. The success event is the honest chain being
[382] extended by one block, increasing its lead by +1,
[383] and the failure event is the attacker\'s chain
[384] being extended by one block, reducing the gap by -1.
[386] The probability of an attacker catching up from a
[387] given deficit is analogous to a Gambler\'s Ruin
[388] problem. Suppose a gambler with unlimited credit
[389] starts at a deficit and plays potentially an
[390] infinite number of trials to try to reach
[391] breakeven. We can calculate the probability he
[392] ever reaches breakeven, or that an attacker ever
[393] catches up with the honest chain, as follows[^8]:
[395] $\qquad$ p = probability an honest node finds the next block
[397] $\qquad$ q = probability the attacker finds the next block
[399] $\qquad$ qz = probability the attacker will ever catch up
[400]               from z blocks behind
[402] $$\begin{aligned}
[404] \begin{cases}
[405] 1               & \text{if } p \leqslant q\\
[406] \left(q/p\right)^z & \text{if } p > q
[407] \end{cases}
[408] \end{aligned}$$
[410] Given our assumption that p \> q, the probability
[411] drops exponentially as the number of blocks the
[412] attacker has to catch up with increases. With the
[413] odds against him, if he doesn\'t make a lucky
[414] lunge forward early on, his chances become
[415] vanishingly small as he falls further behind.
[417] We now consider how long the recipient of a new
[418] transaction needs to wait before being
[419] sufficiently certain the sender can\'t change the
[420] transaction. We assume the sender is an attacker
[421] who wants to make the recipient believe he paid
[422] him for a while, then switch it to pay back to
[423] himself after some time has passed. The receiver
[424] will be alerted when that happens, but the sender
[425] hopes it will be too late
[427] The receiver generates a new key pair and gives
[428] the public key to the sender shortly before
[429] signing. This prevents the sender from preparing a
[430] chain of blocks ahead of time by working on it
[431] continuously until he is lucky enough to get far
[432] enough ahead, then executing the transaction at
[433] that moment. Once the transaction is sent, the
[434] dishonest sender starts working in secret on a
[435] parallel chain containing an alternate version of
[436] his transaction.
[438] The recipient waits until the transaction has been
[439] added to a block and z blocks have been linked
[440] after it. He doesn\'t know the exact amount of
[441] progress the attacker has made, but assuming the
[442] honest blocks took the average expected time per
[443] block, the attacker\'s potential progress will be
[444] a Poisson distribution with expected value:
[446] $$\lambda = z \frac{q}{p}$$
[448] To get the probability the attacker could still
[449] catch up now, we multiply the Poisson density for
[450] each amount of progress he could have made by the
[451] probability he could catch up from that point:
[453] $$\begin{aligned}
[454] \sum _{k=0}^\infty \frac{\lambda ^k e^{-\lambda}}{k!} \cdot
[455] \begin{cases}
[456] \left(q/p\right)^{(z-p)} & \text{if } k \leqslant z \\
[457] 1                     & \text{if } k > z
[458] \end{cases}
[459] \end{aligned}$$
[461] Rearranging to avoid summing the infinite tail of
[462] the distribution\...
[465] \frac{\lambda ^k e^{-\lambda}}{k!}
[466] \left(1 - \left(q/p\right)^{(z-k)}\right)$$
[468] Converting to C code\...
[471] #include <math.h>
[472] double AttackerSuccessProbability(double q, int z)
[474]     double p = 1.0 - q;
[475]     double lambda = z * (q / p);
[476]     double sum = 1.0;
[477]     int i, k;
[480]         double poisson = exp(-lambda);
[482]             poisson *= lambda / i;
[483]         sum -= poisson * (1 - pow(q / p, z - k));
[485]     return sum;
[489] Running some results, we can see the probability
[490] drop off exponentially with z.
[522] Solving for P less than 0.1%\...
[536] ## Conclusion
[538] We have proposed a system for electronic
[539] transactions without relying on trust. We started
[540] with the usual framework of coins made from
[541] digital signatures, which provides strong control
[542] of ownership, but is incomplete without a way to
[543] prevent double-spending. To solve this, we
[544] proposed a peer-to-peer network using
[545] proof-of-work to record a public history of
[546] transactions that quickly becomes computationally
[547] impractical for an attacker to change if honest
[548] nodes control a majority of CPU power. The network
[549] is robust in its unstructured simplicity. Nodes
[550] work all at once with little coordination. They do
[551] not need to be identified, since messages are not
[552] routed to any particular place and only need to be
[553] delivered on a best effort basis. Nodes can leave
[554] and rejoin the network at will, accepting the
[555] proof-of-work chain as proof of what happened
[556] while they were gone. They vote with their CPU
[557] power, expressing their acceptance of valid blocks
[558] by working on extending them and rejecting invalid
[559] blocks by refusing to work on them. Any needed
[560] rules and incentives can be enforced with this
[561] consensus mechanism.
[563] ## References
[566]         <http://www.weidai.com/bmoney.txt>, 1998.
[568] [^2]: H.  Massias, X.S. Avila, and J.-J. Quisquater,
[569]         \'Design of a secure timestamping service
[570]         with minimal trust requirements,\'
[571]         In 20th Symposium on Information Theory in
[572]         the Benelux, May 1999.
[574] [^3]: S.  Haber, W.S. Stornetta, \'How to time-stamp
[575]         a digital document,\' In Journal of Cryptology,
[578] [^4]: D.  Bayer, S. Haber, W.S. Stornetta, \'Improving
[579]         the efficiency and reliability of digital
[580]         time-stamping,\' In Sequences II: Methods in
[581]         Communication, Security and Computer Science,
[584] [^5]: S.  Haber, W.S. Stornetta, \'Secure names for
[585]         bit-strings,\' In Proceedings of the 4th ACM
[586]         Conference on Computer and Communications
[587]         Security, pages 28-35, April 1997.
[589] [^6]: A.  Back, \'Hashcash - a denial of service
[590]         counter-measure,\'
[591]         <http://www.hashcash.org/papers/hashcash.pdf>,
[594] [^7]: R.C. Merkle, \'Protocols for public key
[595]         cryptosystems,\' In Proc. 1980 Symposium on
[596]         Security and Privacy, IEEE Computer Society,
[599] [^8]: W.  Feller, \'An introduction to probability
[600]         theory and its applications,\' 1957.
